review_title: Great place & excellent engineers but pulled down by bureaucracy and middle management
pros:
Great engineers and perhaps the best place to work if you are a network guy or IP guy. Information sharing within company is excellent and there will be dozens of people coming forward to share with you when you shout for help.
The single best aspect of benefits/work is flexible timings. No one asks you what time you are coming or going as long you deliver the results.
Training is wonderful and opportunities to learn are tremendous. Connecting & networking aspects are great if you are in the consulting or sales roles.
cons:
Single biggest problem is bureaucracy. you'd be surprised to see the amount of documentation required for "internal processes" and most of the times you spend time internally rather than externally. i.e. with Customer.
Top management is OK but the problem lies @ middle layer. most of the times they've their own agendas and its frustrating to manage the different agendas.
Work-life balance is quite bad as most of the time you're lost in the tons of emails, documents and ever lasting meetings/webex calls. If you happen to be in the technical sales then literally you work almost every day including weekends & public holidays due to the "urgent requests" from customers and AM's.
Heavy focus on USA makes things difficult for people working in rest of the regions too..

review_title: Truly a great place to work
pros: Clean, uncluttered office with great views, intelligent use of collaboration technology, choose between an X1 Carbon ThinkPad or Macbook Pro as your primary laptop, good mobile/VPN access on tablets/smartphones so you can literally work anywhere on any device, diverse and inclusive culture, regular social events in the office (with wine sometimes), company-supported participation in mass events like SGX Bull Run, JP Morgan corporate challenge, up to 5 days of "Time to Give" which employees can use to perform volunteer work, company matches up to US$10K per employee for every hour of volunteer work performed, CSR activity included on every team offsite event, trustworthy and professional colleagues, regular communication from senior leadership, great internal platforms for learning, including access to LinkedIn Learning and other external learning platforms
cons: Sometimes complex internal processes, few opportunities for promotion (people tend to stay unless made redundant), very challenging business environment despite strong leadership in most market segments and solid product/solution portfolio

review_title: Still a good company, but increasingly losing its shine as good employer..
pros:
- telecommute, freedom to work anywhere
- fairly good compensation
- strong brand, big company with lots of technologies and departments for you to move around
- well regarded if Cisco on resume
cons:
- a company that keeps retrenching and restructuring just to please shareholders
- change every year for change sake.. many of the changes are just for show
- losing its shine to be good employer as it removes staff everywhere, only to rehire 6-12 months later.. waste time, waste resources to retrain, lose employee's general morale.. increasingly employees don't feel loyal unlike the Year 2000-2007 where employees would love to stay and not leave...now employees only work for position, pay and glory politics..
- slower growth due to hardware focus even though it is trying to move more to software and services..

review_title: Cisco is a challenging place to work and given its size there continues to be an opaque approach to promotions
pros: Makes you very focused and objective driven. You learn to mange stakeholders and if you are iron willed are steeled into managing internal conflicts and or rivalries to help achieve your objectives.
cons: There is a lack of recognition of your efforts at present. Management also needs to improve it's system of reallocating and or restructuring for even good performers and team players.

pros: Cisco has a great technology portfolio albeit huge, the people are great to work with and have a winning culture, thought leadership is inspiring - although it can sometimes be so far in the future it is difficult to execute effectively with channel partners, work-life balance is excellent,
cons: Constant change - as in regional management reshuffle, strategy and structural changes follow the frequency of management change and the constant downsizing every year means a paranoid and political survival culture is developing and with the organisation announcing 4 months before it actually happens full sales productivity in the year is reduced to only about 6 months

review_title: Has potential to be the best
pros: The very best technology in the market today. Progressive thinking in positioning for a dynamic and ever changing market place. Seamless way of working from outside the office using the device of your choice. Fantastic work-life balance policies. Good work rotation opportunities. Mentoring of employees a plus.
cons: Compensation lags behind major players in the industry. Decisions can take a long time to make. IT systems not optimised nor integrated in many areas. Operational deficiencies make it difficult to make things work. Career opportunities not present once you get to middle management.

review_title: 600 pound gorilla figuring its way in the woods but won't ask for directions
pros: telecommuting from work, flexibility (which means round-the-clock at times), friendly people all over, compensation is on-par if not better than its competitors, transparency
cons: playing catch-up while pushing its weight on to competitors, employee morale low due to 'limited-restructuring', no one dares to challenge the status quo-some did and was sidelined, general prospects are gloomy, not a great place for young people, gen-y, millennials

pros:
Having been at Cisco for a couple of months its apparent that Cisco has indeed nurtured a very collaborative and transparent culture. The technology we sell to customer resonates very well with the Cisco culture. As we provide top-notch networking capabilities to our customers, as a Cisco employee, I always find myself being able to be directed to the right person at the right time to get the job done.

Everyone is friendly and approachable, most importantly helpful as we work in cross functional teams.
cons: Being a giant, some processes do need to be streamlined and therefore, Cisco is actively sifting through its processes to help us employees move things faster by simplification of processes.

review_title: Great company, but depending on your colleagues, work place
job_title: Sales Business Development Manager in Singapore
pros: Great technology firm, excellent breadth of solutions so you can move horizontally. Flexible work, once you used to it, you can never leave this place. Excellent middle-top management and clear goals to measure performance. Very liberal training policy, and not so bad travel policy.
cons: Groups based on your country, or some demographics. That's the horrible part. Many jobs, decades old IT systems, Heavy workloads, and worse of all is the information overflow. There are tons of files with old information, and many versions/revisions but you need plenty of luck to find the correct information. So indirectly you'll end up relying on people.

pros:
(1) Flexible working arrangements
(2) Empowerment to all levels
(3) Open and encouraging environment: Anything is possible
(4) Great collaboration and team work
cons:
(1) As with other US MNCs, Cisco starting to hire and fire people
(2) While we see cost cutting measures eg moving office out of expensive rental and multiple rounds of restructuring being executed, there are some strange practises such as introducing additional allowances to senior executives and increase travel.
(3) Lack of appropriate support/backup during vacation/hospital leave
(4) US eccentric-Worldwide teams need to be more holistic when introducing policies and programs.

pros:
The people and the culture! Cisco looks after employees' wellness and  work life balance.  In my role, I am able to work with very diverse, fun and smart people on a daily basis. 

Access to fantastic technology also brings the already flexible work environment to the next level. We can stay connected anywhere without feeling any real difference whichever location you are in, may it be in one of the colorful couches or rooms in the office or at the comfort of your own home.
cons: Not really a con... Office location in some countries are not centrally located (but then again this is subjective as to where I am staying).

pros:

cons:
- Hot-desking (no individual desk) leading to no "sense of belonging"
- Excessive use of collaboration, "back-to-back webex calls" starting at 07h30am
- Overworked/Overstressed staff never available for informal discussions
- Overcompetitive career-conscious Managers stressing out their staff

review_title: Great place to Work Live Play and Learn, if your in the right place in Cisco
pros:
1. Cisco folks are smart, experienced, diverse, culturally exposed, very professional and quite friendly. Collaboration is part of daily work and people are willing to help out. 

2. Technology is everywhere, and Cisco eats its own dog food, just not the latest release. The portfolio of products in Cisco will simply amaze people. 

3. Individual contributors are empowered to make critical decisions, access people across the company towards identified goals in a relatively flat hierarchy. 

4. Awesome work life balance, you decide how much you want to work and earn, now with mobility and great tools, where doesn't really matter. You can use Apple, PC, iPhone, BB, Android, IT is heading towards any to any device. Which is great for tech savvy folks 

5. Overall package is average with good medical coverage.
cons:
1. Compensation package are sometimes mediocre at best, promotions and pay increments can take eons. Loyalty is rewarded by stagnation in grade level, however we welcome jumpers back with higher grade, pay and recognition. 

2. Personal growth and career can be on both ends of the spectrum, depending on your manager, which team and where ? Markets with high growth reasonably gets resources and attention. 

Along the lines of its acquisition and develop strategy, talent seems to be managed the same way. Rarely find young people in Cisco, mostly IT old timers, reliable and dependable. This makes things dull and mundane at times. 

3. Cisco finds innovative ways to complicate doing business, which in turn complicate most peoples jobs. 

4. Too many initiatives, too many programs, too many tools "everything in Cisco is online somewhere, if you can find it then great". 

5. Cisco culture is beginning to be diluted in certain places, from an awesome company its starting to be just another IT company. Yet whats most disturbing is on the surface things are ok.

pros: Work life balance, flexible working arrangement, very global perspective. Quite competitive starting pay when you get into the job and then it stagnants.
cons: Appraisal and recognition process is ambiguous, not structured and not transparent. Do not expect yearly increment and your pay will be below market rate very soon if you stay there for 2-3 years or more. Some folks can be more interested to make themselves more visible to management to get the promotion than focus on doing the job - they make this a competition.

job_title: Manager, Network Services in San Jose, CA
pros:
I decided to wait almost a year after leaving the company before posting a review.  The primary reason being is that when you decide to leave an organization it is usually because there is something there that isn't aligning with you or what you want anymore however, the grass is not always greener someplace else.  This has been my experience.  In fact, the appreciation I have for the company has grown so much in my time away that I would really like to return.

The company truly believes on promoting within and as an employee you are encouraged to grow your career within the organization and learn new skills by taking different positions.  Benefits are excellent.  Cisco is the industry leader for networking and now cloud.  It is sometimes easy to forget that on the daily grind but you are working for the company that everyone looks to for network and infrastructure standards.  Culture within the business units managing product lines give you a lot of freedom to be innovative and creative in your approach to your role.  In most cases you are given a fair amount of autonomy and control over how you do your job provided that it aligns with the strategic objectives.  Benefits, 401k match, RSUs and ESPP are amazing.  And while the salaries aren't the top of the industry, they are above market and pretty competitive.
cons:
Cisco can be a machine.  There isn't an overt demand for all of your time (even the time outside of work) but more of a subtle, slight encouragement to always be on.  If you are not careful, you will live, sleep and eat Cisco 24x7.  Don't get me wrong, this is 100% a choice and if you are aware of this subtlety in the culture it is very easy to set appropriate boundaries that will be respected by the company and leadership team.

If you don't like where you are in Cisco or what you are working on, give it 6 months because you will be reorg'd.  While it is sometimes necessary to realign the company to meet competitive threats or market demands, reorganizing the company once a year is excessive and tends to create a distrusting environment for the rank and file which makes being a leader in the organize challenging.  There is a loss of momentum and motivation that occurs a few months before and a few months after reorgs so this leaves the company being effective at delivery and execution only about 70% of the time.

While Cisco attracts some bright, motivated people the truth of the matter is you are either cut out for the company and its culture or you're not.  If you aren't it will be painfully obvious to you and those around you.  Sadly as a leader it is hard to cut dead weight from the team and the only really accepted way is via layoffs, which is why the company reorgs once a year despite the company line about the reorgs.

job_title: Account Manager in Research Triangle Park, NC
pros: High-Quality Products: Cisco's products are known for their high quality, reliability, and performance. This makes them a popular choice for businesses of all sizes. Advanced Security Features: Cisco's security appliances are some of the most advanced in the industry, with features like intrusion prevention, firewall, and VPN capabilities. Excellent Technical Support: Cisco offers excellent technical support to its customers, with a variety of resources available online, as well as phone and email support.
cons: Limited Customization: Cisco's products can be less customizable than those of some of its competitors, which can be a drawback for businesses with specific needs. Steep Learning Curve: Cisco's products require a certain level of technical expertise to use effectively, which can be a barrier to adoption for some businesses. Competition: Cisco faces competition from other networking equipment and services providers, which can make it challenging to maintain market share and profitability over time.

job_title: Systems Architect in Research Triangle Park, NC
pros: Flexibility. This job is very flexible. Work-Life balance is extraordinary. To the point where most of us work 15 hours a week or less, or from the car. Health, 401k Benefits are great.
cons: Diversity and Inclusion is the highest priority in the company. Some might see this as a Pro, but let me explain. Unqualified people have been shuffled around the company into leadership roles during and after COVID, some have grown to be successful, while many have failed completely, which casacades and causes multiple leadership failures down to the engineers. Many great engineers have left due to the failures of our recently promoted leadership. ESG is such a high focus that our products are failing simple quality checks. We have had many customers leave Cisco products for Palo Alto or other vendors simply because our products are garbage now, and the TAC support is atrocious. Be prepared for an annual layoff here, generally every year there is a fat trimming movement where useless roles are removed, allowing the folks to transfer to other parts of the company, where they are utterly useless. Customer Experience is a nightmare., where the Customer is put 2nd, and profits are put 1st. CX BCS contracts are the worst thing for delivery - nonsense deliverables that the customer does not have any desire for. It's purely a moneygrab by Cisco

pros: Great work culture and managers. Lot of projects (work) is available and people are available to help everywhere. The team culture in general is great across all teams. If you have to do anything with networks and networks is your long term career goal then there is absolutely no better place than Cisco. There is a LOT of training available , high end labs with tons of devices and opportunities to do so many industry level certificates and all this is free of cost.
cons: At the end of the day it is a network support role after all. Even if you might take up a lot of automation python projects but you have to take care of your cases/.backlog. You might feel burnt out in few high severity cases as well (very similar to what software devs face when their 'feature' is about to 'go live') but that gets easier with time and experience. The nature of the job can be viewed in 2 ways : Positive : You are Sherlock Holmes who has to investigate and use your skills on multiple cases. Negative : Your work basically starts when things are going wrong. So you are almost always. dealing with a mental 'timer' as they are people waiting for you to provide solutions or answers and most of the times it is not easy. Multiple logs , timestamps, data correlation and since you are not the one who has written the code. Except few rare days mostly you will have a lot of emails to write and multiple logs to check. Salary growth can be slow ( as far as I am aware 10-18% is standard) however if your communication with management is positive and your manager assures you then it can be worth the wait. Exponential increment after a span of 2-3 years is common I have heard. This will vary a lot based on an individual's exp and work they have put in so not really a con. Lot of mandatory trainings :-P

pros: Pro's They're well made, reliable, and tend to function for a very long time without going down. Well supported--it's very easy to find documentation on how to do something, or a company/person who can do whatever it is you want done for you. Very large feature set. Cisco offers numerous open standard and proprietary protocols and options in their code that other vendors lack parity with. Stable code and quick bug fixes. Bugs that cause major operational or security problems have been extremely rare, in my experience. Most products have a CLI that is easy to use and understand.
cons: Con's Price. Sometimes I think Cisco should be spelled Ci$co. Complex licensing. One could invest as much time learning their licensing schemes as you would studying for a CCIE. Inconsistencies between products. Cisco has acquired numerous companies and incorporated their products into Cisco's portfolio while retaining much of the code base--this leads to many quirks when working in the CLI's on multiple products. Most GUI software is written in Java and can do a lot of dumb things--specifically the ADSM software used to configure ASA's. Occasional interoperability issues when connecting to products from other vendors. Software releases can be a bit confusing, as figuring out which features you're getting is not always clear.

pros:
The company has great benefits and seems to truly care about their employees. There is lots of opportunities inside and the work-life balance its ok.
100% remote and flexible time.

Benefits:
-Childcare vouchers
-Annual bonus
-Pension Plan
-Stocks (discount of 15% for employees)
-Health insurance (extended to family, partner and descendents)
-Life insurance (42x base salary)
-All cisco certifications and trainings available and paid by cisco
-Training platforms (o'reilly, linkedin videos, udemy, harvard training, Pluralsight, MasterClass, Coursera,getAbstract)
-400 euros to spend on personal classes, health, medicines, etc
-Car and gas for tech leads (grade 11),
cons:
The management is really poor.
Everyone that wants to be a manager can become one. It doesn't matter if you'll be a good manager or not, if you want you just work your way out to it. And that's how you become a bad manager and end-up ruining a whole team :)

The problem is that we have lazy and poor managers, managing senior and high performing engineers.

By micro managing, tons of bureaucratic processes and lack of transparency makes the life of engineers frustrating and pretty damn boring.

But it's a matter of luck, I had one good manager, a so-so manager, and now a terrible manager, so good luck with that.

This lack of transparency and bureaucracy is making cisco lose the best talent to other top companies and competitors, but the guys in the top probably don't see that.

Well I like the company, I like the colleagues, but don't trust the management and specially my manager, that's why I'm looking to move out :)

review_title: Toxicity is an everyday experience at Cisco Systems.
pros: - Cisco has a great reputation as the industry leader in a lot of areas, particularly networking hardware and datacenter equipment, thus working at Cisco obviously is a good addition to your resume. (However the Cisco reputation is not the same as it used to be) - The offices are pretty amazing with state of the art facilities. You do not get much time to use these facilities though. But they're there. We had a mini cinema hall in the Bangalore office. It doesn't get any better than that. - Work from home option, in some teams, is quite flexible. - A well connected pickup and dropoff cab service in the Bangalore office (Not free, but costs about Rs. 2000 per month)
cons: Where to begin - There is zero involvement from HR whatsoever. If your director/manager is exploiting you, which by the way is extremely common, you have no one to help you. Only your teammates, who are probably also being exploited. - You are completely at the mercy of your direct and second level bosses. If your team is toxic (my experience), you will suffer a lot. In the many years I have been in Cisco Bangalore, I have seen so many people in a similar situation as me. Helpless, with the only option to look outside Cisco for work. - There is no work-life balance whatsoever. If you have a geolocated team, you are expected to be available for work/meetings in all timezones. 'Night meetings' are ubiquitous and you are expected to work on weekends too. - Layoffs are so frequent that even before the upcoming layoff occurs, rumors of the next layoff are commonplace. Who is going to be laid off doesn't matter at all on the person's merit or capability, but on the relationship they have with their manager and director. - Promotion cycles get cancelled very frequently. Bonuses are more or less always meagre, with a company factor, usually below 100%, which means you get a lower bonus than your bonus target just because the overall company is always under performing. - The CEO is an ex-sales VP, who's only focussed on profits. Since Cisco is losing market share and yearly revenues are always less than $50bn, Chuck Robbins' method for maintaining profits and consequently dividends is to hire execs with the mission to lay off a huge chunk of their teams in the so called 'streamlining' initiatives. All you hear in Cisco is layoffs. - Cisco's policy of internally promoting managers based on years of service rather than capability has filled Cisco's ranks of managers with incompetant managers (and even directors) who are more suited for tech lead or project management positions. They lack vision and foresight, and are only focussed on the present. Something I feel resonates all the way to the top with Chuck Robbins and his team in many regards. - The pay, in comparison to comparable roles in comparable companies, is always low. There is huge attrition which leads to lots of instability. It's been a tremendous challenge planning projects since teams are always transient. - The hiring process for Cisco is to hire people cheap who will be able to 'do the job' rather than 'invent new products'. Getting hired by Cisco is no longer a big deal. Thus there is a huge upsurge of converting red badge employees, who are from vendor companies, to blue badge full Cisco employees. This ensures the business is run... but not changed. Cisco loses innovation and invention, and consequently its leading edge. This problem is spread across almost all teams. - There are so many layers between you and the customer, that you will probably never get the opportunity to talk to a customer directly. Which basically means you slowly lose knowledge of what the market wants. Thus when you apply outside for a new role, you know what your manager/director wants, but not what the customers want.

Salary,

review_title: Administrative positions at Cisco are all hourly pay.
job_title: Administrative Assistant in San Francisco, CA
pros: This posting is only wrt to the pay for an administrative role at Cisco Systems; I wrote another posting about the company and the culture and values under a different log in. It's overall a great place to work. But if you haven't worked as an hourly employee for a while, here are some of the pros and cons. The main positive thing about it is overtime and double time. You know those happy hour parties that you, the admin, manages until the wee hours, sometimes including clean up and strike? You get paid 1.5x your regular hourly rate for more than 8 hours and less than 12 hours, and then if you go over 12 hours, you get paid 2x your hourly rate for that hour or more. As long as your tax withholdings are set up correctly, this can be a huge, huge benefit.
cons: I left in 2019; perhaps it has changed since then, and it may be different depending on which business unit you are in. But a huge con is having to log your hours. The tool they use is an Oracle nightmare that's literally fresh out of 2006. Just having to use it in and of itself could be a big headache. If you miss the deadline, they pay you for the full 80 hours of your pay period, you just have to back-file for any missing overtime. Again, this review is only about the pros-cons of getting paid on an hourly basis as an administrative assistant. The other cons to getting paid hourly in a job that is typically part of the salaried crew is that you might have to get permission to add hours, and you might sometimes do work in the unapproved time anyway just because you have a strong work ethic and don't want to have to handle the fall out if a ball is dropped, essentially not charging for 100% of your work product just because of your boss's budget pressures. When I started there I didn't feel like I had to worry too much about how many hours I was working; I was hired to cover executive support for multiple high-level C-level and VP execs which is a more-than-full-time type of job. But then when company structure, politics and budget changes meant that my boss had to ask me to only put in 40 hours a week, my whole outlook on my position at the company changed. It meant essentially that I'd have to deliver a smaller work product to all of my execs, which in my line of work basically doesn't exist without loss of reputation. And then I got recruited away to my next role, which solved the problem. And let me tell you, I *do not* miss the timecard interface!

job_title: Director, Business Intelligence in San Jose, CA
pros: Cisco as a company has a culture that cares for people. While every large company has its pro's and con's at its core, Cisco cares about its employees and does a lot for them. While I have seen bad things happen to good people due to poor leadership/management, I can say that when that behavior was properly surfaced, Cisco leadership engages and solves the problem.
cons:
1. There is a lot of leadership churn. When leaders churn, their initiatives go with them. Teams that were spun up to drive the next big initiative go away without ever being given the chance to make the initiative a reality. People get frustrated and take their talents elsewhere.

2. The Executive Leadership Team lives in a different Cisco than the rest of the organization. The ELT has a passion and a vision for the future of Cisco that does not really make it past the SVP level to folks doing the work. The messaging from the SVP's is often convoluted, disjointed and simply out of alignment with ELT statements. There is no company wide goal management system like Google's OKR's or Salesforce V2MOMs to help rank and file team members stay aligned with ELT expectations.

job_title: Customer Delivery Leader in San Francisco, CA
pros:
- Executive leadership communicates honestly and openly

 - The company promotes lateral movement and promotion to both cultivate internal talent and prevent attrition

 - Leadership has a keen sense of the organization's strengths and weaknesses 

 - Evolving product lines and strategic acquisitions outpace product commoditization

 - An emphasis is placed on the customer journey - even if employees on the ground ignore it. 

 - Most of the people I met enjoyed their job, genuinely wanted to add value, and came across as open and collaborative.

 - Clear limits are put in place to make sure that customers are fully supported when new products are introduced. I can't overstate how refreshing this was.
cons:
- Sales teams seem to be split into warring factions.  This, coupled with a  lack of clear structure leads to a lot of redundancy, wasted resources, and ambiguous goals. The end result is a hamster wheel of day-to-day fire drills. 

 - For all of the talk about customer focus, most employees seem to be obsessed with internal politics.

pros:
1. Great place to learn, amazing experts, who are eager to share their knowledge
2. Atmosphere of mutual respect, kindness, openness, being part of the team that has common goals
3. Atmosphere that promotes sharing knowledge, teaching, learning
4. Managers are mostly not bosses but leaders who help you grow, who are holding your back and are caring for their teams and every individual
cons:
1. In my location salaries are reaaaaallly lagging behind competitors.
2. Rotation of workers is too fast, due to lagging salaries or organisational changes. All companies should focus on retaining employees because right now the fastest way of getting higher salary or promotion is to change your job/position. Costs and time of onboarding software engineers to complex projects is tremendous - it's not accounting or selling which everywhere is rather the same - and companies should do everything not only to get the right people but also actively encourage them to stay.
3. Too many wannabe PMs with their powerpoints, MBAs and 'groundbreaking strategies' and not enough developers.
4. Forcing 'new strategies', by PMs or other middle-management guys who want to show how important they are, which bring only chaos.
5. Inequality between wages by country - I don't believe that engineers in San Fransisco are 10 times more efficient or work 10 times harder than people in Europe, Asia etc.

job_title: Sales Operations Analyst in London, England
pros: You have the backing of a well rooted company in Cisco. Job security isn’t top of mind.
cons: It seems Cisco is realising it make a mistake with AppDynamics. The product has stagnated, new product roll-outs are fraught with deep technical issues, the revenue generated by AppDynamics pales in comparison with other acquisition companies. As such, budget is non-existent, hiring freezes are the new norm, and attrition is only increasing Whilst Cisco figures out a path forward for this ailing acquisition. Sales culture is deeply toxic, borderline abusive in some cases. Pay is unbelievably disparate, support teams are woefully underpaid and under resourced. You will be worked into the ground, it doesn’t matter the role you are in.

review_title: Best company for work life balance, good benefits and culture, but bad internal growth
pros:
Best for work life balance. Some teams have less than 2 or 3 hours of work a day. I myself had just about 6 hours of work a week for a good period of time after I automated a few of my tasks (not possible in TAC teams though).
Job security even during layoffs (India only)
You get a chance to learn new technologies, internal movement etc. Can grow skills during the downtime since work doesnt usually take up too much time. 
Company is very employee centric, you will get time off, benefits and support. Eg. Company went above and beyond during Covid crisis giving all employees in India 50k as a one time bonus irrespective of grade. They also helped with medical care and expenses in many cases. The Cisco India community is very kind and supportive (helped arrange beds and oxygen etc).
Feels amazing to be working at a place where you can learn a lot. The resources we have at our disposal to skill up is amazing - especially for those in networking domain. Just dont stay in boring roles like BCS and move to better teams.
cons:
Use the free time wisely. A lot of people get stagnant and lose skills due to ample free time and not skilling up. Cisco does not have good growth in terms of pay. If you get stuck with boring work, change teams.
The pay disparity is huge. Over 50% pay difference in many cases between people in same roles with same skills. Pay seems to be more about experience than skills - something that resembles a government company (could be a good thing for many since there is job security). 
The TAC teams are especially bleeding talent due to terrible pay that has not kept up with industry. Freshers make more money than skilled, experienced folks who tend to leave to competitors. This has resulted in terrible support experience for customers. Most TAC cases globally are handled by folks with less product experience from Bangalore since the senior folks leave for better pay. 
Some teams are better placed in terms of decision making, benefits, product trainings etc than others. This disparity is often seen in different ways eg. Bangalore folks end up doing back office work and dont lead engagements or interact directly with customer.
Consulting roles which are NOT TAC are amazing for experienced folks looking for relaxation and retirement only and really atrophy the skills of freshers who want to grow and learn.
Do not stay if you want a pay bump. Internal growth is measly and the metrics used to evaluate performance are often gamed. Best to skill up and jump ship.

pros:
This might be a good company for someone who needs an average job that pays bills and doesn't bother too much. Ideal company to retire (or for already retired people).
People are nice and friendly, long holidays, good social activities and food.
cons:
I completely wouldn’t recommend this company for recent graduates, adepts of new technologies, reformers and those who like challenges. It might be even dangerous for fresh people after university: you could pick-up outdated engineering practices and learn only re-invented wheels instead of modern tools. 

Regarding businesses itself, the company totally failed the opportunity when everyone switched to either hybrid or fully remote work. Ask yourself, have you ever heard about Webex at all (software or devices)? You might have heard about Skype, Zoom, even BlueJeans , but not about video conferencing devices developed mainly at Oslo, Norway.

I also want to highlight the following cons:
- missing onboarding process
- processes are vague in general
- close to zero internal documentation
- outdated technologies and engineering practices
- small R&D investments
- engineers with “senior” titles are weak as engineers
- communications between departments have seen better days
- politics, a lot

job_title: Business Analyst in Research Triangle Park, NC
pros: Pay is good and I am bonus eligible. Work/life balance is also good.
cons:
Work from home is a thing that is not going away. They have pushed the back to work plan every month since June. If you like working from home, Cisco is the place for you.

Everything peripheral to the business is social justice oriented. Again, if that's your thing, Cisco is the place for you. You cant buy a notepad in the company store without being hit over the head about how part of the proceeds go to a social justice initiative. I'd rather my workplace be apolitical.

Little to no training. There is very much a, "Welcome to Cisco, here is a list of names of people who you might need to know. Figure it out. But feel free to ask questions.", attitude that is being addressed, but it's still a thing.

I've been here for a year now and I haven't even had a performance review. So, if I'm doing a good job, I don't know it. If I'm not, I don't know it. And if either of those things are the case, I don't know how to keep doing well or how to do better. I'm still figuring it out.
